title: I am the joint account holder and a bank levy has been placed on my joint account with judgement debtor, a friend.
question: I am a joint account holder and the other person on the account, a friend, had a bank levy against our joint account. I have not been in contact with this friend but just continued to use the account. All the funds in the account are 100% mine. Can i file and exemption and get my money back. I am overdue on my rent due to funds being held.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Joint accounts during bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Court basics
answers:
This is why attorneys discourage joint titling of properties.

I agree with Mr. Eschen: You can file a third party claim pursuant to CCP sections 720.110, et seq. Since the California Judicial Council does not provide any fill-in-the-blank forms for this type of claim, you'll need either to hire an attorney to prepare it for you, or to visit your local public law library and ask the reference librarian to help you find a form. (The Matthew Bender publications are good resources.) Mail the claim to the levying officer (usually the county sheriff) who levied the bank account. He will then send a copy to the judgment creditor, who will decide either to (1) ignore the claim and let the sheriff return the funds to the account or (2) oppose the claim and set the matter for court hearing.

You should be able to prove that your funds are not your friend's funds. If you can prove this, you should be able to get your money back. You will have to be able to trace the funds to yourself and not your friend.

Technically, you would file a third-party claim, for which there is no official form. Unfortunately, you would not get your money back for some time. The judgment creditor has 30 days to object to your claim. In that time, he might file a bond, which would prevent the sheriff from releasing the funds.

When you do get your money back, you are going to put it in your new bank account in your name alone, along with all your other money.
